title: About
text:
Professional Summary
A skilled Technical Analyst with over two years of experience in development, implementation, and support. Expertise in diagnostics, troubleshooting, and managing large datasets. Known for identifying process inefficiencies and delivering actionable insights. Recognized for innovative problem-solving abilities and strong communication skills, with a passion for Data Science, Big Data Analytics, and Software Development.


Accomplishments
Awarded KPMG Encore Awards – Rising Star, within two months of employment.


Skills
Strong communication skills
Proficient in Microsoft Office
SQL and Python
Expertise in data collection, mining, and analysis
Experience in roaming and network maintenance
Business valuation and process workflow


Work Experience
Front-End Team Member, Woolworths Supermarkets, Melbourne (03/2024 – Present)
Provided excellent customer service and communication, ensuring a positive shopping experience.
Managed point-of-sale (POS) systems efficiently and handled customer inquiries.
Led team activities to ensure smooth store operations.
Processed and dispatched online orders, maintaining accuracy and timeliness.
Technical Analyst, KPMG, India (07/2022 – 02/2024)
Supported the roaming function of leading operators in the Middle East, creating reliable systems to track international roaming performance.
Coordinated employee training on system updates and best practices.
Experience in IREG testing for voice, GPRS management, and familiarity with GSM testing standards.
Conducted quality assurance and control of support tickets.
Tested and validated roaming services for GSM, GPRS, LTE, VoLTE, and 5G technologies.
Contributed to creating a risk control matrix for a leading African telecom organization, identifying gaps and providing recommendations.
GRCS Intern, KPMG, India (01/2022 – 07/2022)
Worked on proposals and engagements involving large datasets, using Hadoop and SQL for data extraction and transformation.
Developed KPIs and generated analytical reports.
Managed daily communications with roaming partners, averaging 30 interactions per day.
Actively contributed to team meetings, offering insights for problem-solving and innovation.
Assisted in completing projects from concept to implementation.

title: Rising Vehicle Prices and Market Segmentation: Analyzing Trends from 2023 to 2025
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(forcats)
library(lubridate)

vehicles_data <- read_csv("Data/vehicles_dataset.csv")

# Data cleaning: Remove rows with missing 'year' or 'price'
vehicles_clean <- vehicles_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(year) & !is.na(price))

# Optional: Remove extreme outliers in 'price' (e.g., top/bottom 1%)
vehicles_clean <- vehicles_clean %>%
  filter(price > quantile(price, 0.01), price < quantile(price, 0.99))


Problem Description
The automotive industry is rapidly evolving, and one of the critical questions both consumers and industry professionals ask is whether newer cars are always more expensive. By analyzing a dataset of over 9,000 vehicles, including their production year (2023 to 2025) and prices, this blog explores how vehicle prices have changed over time and whether newer vehicles consistently command higher prices.


Data Description
The dataset used in this analysis was sourced from Kaggle and includes information on vehicle prices and specifications for cars produced between 2023 and 2025. Key variables include: -

Year: The production year of the vehicle.
Price: The listed price of the vehicle in USD.
Make: The manufacturer of the vehicle (e.g., Toyota, Ford).
Model: The specific model of the vehicle.
Fuel: The type of fuel the vehicle uses.
Mileage: The mileage of the vehicle, typically in miles per gallon (for new vehicles).
Transmission: The type of transmission (e.g., Automatic, Manual).
Body: The type of vehicle body (e.g., SUV, Sedan, Pickup Truck).

Before analyzing the data, cleaning steps included removing missing values and ensuring consistency in the year and price columns. This process ensured that only valid records were used for the analysis.


Analysis
To understand the pricing trends over time, we analyzed the average vehicle prices and their distributions across the years 2023 to 2025. Below are key insights:
1. Average Vehicle Price by Year

avg_price_year <- vehicles_clean %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  summarize(avg_price = mean(price))


ggplot(avg_price_year, aes(x = year, y = avg_price)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue", size = 1) +
  geom_point(color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Average Vehicle Price by Year",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Average Price") +
  theme_minimal()







Figure 1: The average vehicle price from 2023 to 2025 shows an upward trend, with the highest price observed in 2025.





As shown in the Figure 1 above, vehicle prices show a steady increase from 2023 to 2025. The average price in 2023 was around $49,500, which slightly increased in 2024, before a more significant jump in 2025, where the average price exceeds $51,000. This increase may be driven by advancements in technology and global supply chain issues, such as chip shortages.
2. Vehicle Price Distribution by Year

ggplot(vehicles_clean, aes(x = price)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5000, fill = "lightblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Vehicle Price Distribution by Year",
       x = "Price",
       y = "Count") +
  facet_wrap(~ year, scales = "free_y") +
  theme_minimal()







Figure 2: The distribution of vehicle prices across 2023, 2024, and 2025 shows an increasing variation, with distinct pricing tiers observed in 2025.





The histogram in Figure 2, price distribution across the years shows different patterns. In 2023, prices were clustered around the $50,000 to $60,000 range. However, by 2024, the range had widened, with more vehicles priced at both the lower and higher ends of the spectrum. In 2025, distinct pricing tiers became evident, suggesting the market was divided into different segments, including budget, mid-range, and luxury vehicles.


Conclusion
The analysis reveals that newer vehicles tend to be more expensive, with a notable price increase in 2025. The broader range of prices in 2024 and 2025 reflects greater market segmentation, offering consumers more choices in terms of budget, mid-range, and luxury models. These trends are likely influenced by advancements in vehicle technology and market conditions.
Citation:
Jones, M. (2021). The evolution of car prices: How technology and market trends shape the cost of vehicles. Automotive Research Journal.
